conclusion: To determine the magnitude of the external force F applied to slider B, we need to analyze the forces acting on both sliders A and B.
Gravitational force component along the incline: mg sin θ
Normal force: N = mg cos θ
Frictional force: f = μN = μmg cos θ
Slider A is on the verge of not sliding upwards, so the net force along the incline must be zero.
Downward force along the incline: mg sin θ
Frictional force opposing the motion (down the incline): f = μmg cos θ
Tension in the rope (up the incline): T
T = mg sin θ + μmg cos θ
Slider B is also on the verge of not sliding upwards, so the net force along the incline must be zero.
Downward force along the incline: mg sin θ
Frictional force opposing the motion (down the incline): f = μmg cos θ
Tension in the rope (down the incline): T
Horizontal component of F along the incline: F cos θ
Vertical component of F perpendicular to the incline: F sin θ

premise: The normal force on slider B is affected by the vertical component of F
conclusion: N_B = mg cos θ + F sin θ

premise: The frictional force on slider B
conclusion: f_B = μN_B = μ(mg cos θ + F sin θ)
F cos θ = T + mg sin θ + μ(mg cos θ + F sin θ)
